stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the session picking an art style for Course 11 (“Frantic Fleet Factory”). The level starts as a lava-filled construction zone but, after on-stream experimentation, pivots into an offshore oil-rig where Bowser’s minions build and repair airships. Most of the stream is texture, color-palette, and shader prototyping.

development_findings.summary: Initial volcano theme was discarded; the level is now an oil-rig surrounded by a ‘sea’ of oil to give brighter, more varied colors.
development_findings.quote: We’re going with an oil rig most likely … that kind of works for me. That gives us some good color.

development_findings.summary: Layout is still ‘Rico Harbor but with oil’, featuring steel beams over the liquid, multiple small platforms, and a central strike plaza for Bowser’s minions.
development_findings.quote: Imagine this, but all these metal bars are above lava— well, now oil— and that’s the arena you’re walking on.

development_findings.summary: Color palette settled on saturated purple–orange–yellow, with bright yellow infrastructure to separate it from the dark oil sea.
development_findings.quote: Purple-orange-blue… let’s try it. This could look so good. Oh, now I’m excited for this.

development_findings.summary: Implemented a custom N64 combiner shader to create rainbow-sheen oil; required tweaking vertex density, wave maths, and alpha blending; doubling subdivisions improved visual quality at the cost of triangles.
development_findings.quote: I’m gonna admit, that looks cool. Maybe we just power through it— another 10 k triangles, but it’s worth it.

development_findings.summary: Skybox can’t be enlarged with geometry; Kaze notes they will ‘program the skybox’ later so distant ocean can fade properly.
To manage N64 limits, Kaze will break the map into four distinct rig sections connected by long pipes; only one section renders at a time.
development_findings.quote: We need distinct areas… One pipe leads to the neighbouring area so the game isn’t drawing 32 k units at once.

development_findings.summary: Provisional mission plan: M1 – troll working minions; M2 – minion strike; M3 – boss sent to break strike; M4 – power-generator interior; M5 – red coins on scaffolds; secret 8-bit pipe in underwater/ sewer area; Bowser’s office accessible via tall tower.
Visual inspirations referenced: Rico Harbor & Metal Harbor (Sonic), Eldin Volcano (Skyward Sword), Oil Ocean Zone (Sonic 2), Mario Odyssey construction assets, Rusty Bucket Bay (Banjo).

context_findings.summary: Kaze values verbal conciseness and sees it as a core creative skill.
context_findings.quote: Being concise is one of the most important skills in the world.

context_findings.summary: Believes finishing a major SM64 hack requires ‘being mentally ill’ and says he can handle harsh criticism unlike some peers.
context_findings.quote: If you want to finish a major hack you need to be mentally ill… I’m actually just a psychopath, I can take it.

context_findings.summary: Personal life: Zeina (wife) absent writing overdue wedding thank-you cards; Kaze later leaves to dine with her family.
Day job: paid C++ programmer; contracting arrangement emphasises work-life balance and mental-health days.
context_findings.quote: I’m literally paid to code C++. They are so penetrant about mental health.

context_findings.summary: Mentions recent weight-cut (215 → 197 lbs) and current bulking phase.

biobak.summary: Suggested bright yellow structural colors and black-with-orange-highlight oil idea that shaped final palette.
biobak.quote: Black water with orange highlights would look sick as hell.

biobak.summary: Provides ongoing feedback on level visuals; Kaze credits him for spotting purple-desert issue.

badub.summary: Not present live, but Kaze notes Badub will compose music fitting an ‘evil, underwater, menacing but goofy’ construction vibe.

zeina.summary: Absent most of stream due to writing wedding thank-you cards; appears briefly and arranges dinner with Kaze.

key_stories.title: Volcano to Oil-Rig Pivot
key_stories.summary: The level was originally a lava-top construction zone, but visual monotony led Kaze to scrap it mid-stream. Chat (especially Biobak) pushed the idea of an offshore oil rig, providing new color possibilities.
key_stories.challenge: Volcano theme looked too dark and monochrome.
key_stories.process: Reviewed references (Eldin Volcano, Rico Harbor), brainstormed alternatives, accepted chat suggestion of oil.
key_stories.outcome: New setting chosen: oil-rig with sea of oil, enabling brighter palette and new gameplay hooks.
key_stories.key_quote: We’re going with an oil rig most likely… That gives us some good color.

key_stories.title: Rainbow Oil Shader Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted shimmering rainbow highlights on the oil. He experimented with N64 combiner math, fought crashes, and finally doubled vertex density to get convincing specular ripples.
key_stories.challenge: Standard water shader looked like lava and lacked color variation.
key_stories.process: Iterated combiner settings, adjusted wave math, tested IA vs I4 textures, increased subdivision despite performance worries.
key_stories.outcome: Dynamic, psychedelic oil surface that defines the level’s look.
key_stories.key_quote: You start making a level and think, ‘this is dog-shit,’ then one idea hits and suddenly it’s the best thing ever.

key_stories.title: Restructuring for Performance
key_stories.summary: Realising the rig could exceed polygon limits, Kaze decided to split the map into four separate areas connected by pipes, re-mapping missions accordingly.
key_stories.challenge: Single huge rig risked pop-in and FPS drops.
key_stories.process: Discussed polygon budgets, cited tree level precedent, mapped missions to discrete zones.
key_stories.outcome: Modular design that keeps draw distance manageable and creates varied sub-areas.
key_stories.key_quote: We need distinct areas… one pipe leads to a neighbouring area so the game isn’t drawing 32 k units at once.
